messageBody:
You are making Wells's article injustice if you think it's
all about adapting English spelling to various ESL
minorities' pronunciations or abolishing all historical
spellings.

He points out that smallish minorities' pronunciations
can for the most part not be taken into account, but also
that any truly Pan-Anglophone spelling reform. He is in
favor of keeping post-vocalic r, which he hardly would
have done if he had been a hardliner in what he calls the
minimalist camp. I think he makes a good and fair
assessment of the implications of accent differences for
spelling reform - a subject which has been hotly
discussed in this group recently.

Wells also makes a good case for not distinguishing the
lexical sets TRAP-FATHER-BATH (At-Ah in QS terminology) or
LOT-THOUGHT-CLOTH (QS Ox-Awe). For all Read's genius when it
came to Utter-and-Ado he seems to have been overly home-
blind and maximist concerning these lexical sets. I find Awe
and Ah cumbersome to write, and would not shed a tear if
they were abolished, or used only to write foreign names.

Wells also considers not to distinguish STRUT-FOOT-GOOSE (QS
Utter-Foot-Ooze) although he himself is less sure about
that. Read clearly knew what he was doing when deciding not
to distinguish STRUT-About- commA or NURSE- lettER. For the
majority who have split STRUT- FOOT it certainty relieves
many uncertainties and thus anxieties.

One thing Wells doesn't address, but which is of utmost
importance in balancing minimalism and maximalism, is the
balancing of ease of encoding, or writing, against ease of
decoding, or reading. When writing it causes little trouble
if a number of distinctions one makes in speech are lumped
together, but when reading it makes trouble both if too many
distinctions one makes in speech are missing and if too many
distinctions one doesn't make are present. That's exactly
the problem with TO, which not only persists in making
distinctions that were lost before Shakespeare, or already
in Latin or Old French in the case of loanwords, but also in
not making distinctions that have arisen since Shakespeare,
though distinguishing some of the latter in an Pan-
Anglophone spelling might be of doubtful value, as mentioned
above, since their outcome varies across the English-
speaking world.

As for sight-site-cite Read didn't design QS to make
distinctions nobody makes in speech, and rightly so. If we
can use 'make a sighting' or 'make a citation' to make
ourselves clear in ambiguous contexts when speaking we can
do so in writing too. To be sure any respelling based on the
Latin alphabet might look funny for a lot of reasons, pace
Latin and Romance loanwords in Norwegian or Turkish. Thats
one of the reasons I favor QS, the other being that it saves
muscular effort while preserving linearity.

(You would find my foreign accent with undistinguished See-
Zoo and She-J'ai, and with a pronunciation of "mayor" which
is halfway to "measure" as funny as the Filipinos'. I'd
never dream of putting it up as a model for English
spelling, but neither do I expect to see foreign accents
ridiculed by those who advocate spelling reform. Spelling
reform would indeed make things easier for us using English
as an international language, especially to get
pronunciation right.)


/BP 8^)>
--
